result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI (4th) [Modifiers: Penalty - Operating While under the Influence (4th Offense)] and Operating w/ PAC (4th) [Modifiers: Penalty - Operating While under the Influence (4th Offense)]. The defendant was found guilty of OWI (4th) [Modifiers: Penalty - Operating While under the Influence (4th Offense)] and the other charge, Operating w/ PAC (4th) [Modifiers: Penalty - Operating While under the Influence (4th Offense)] was dismissed by the court.

  • Theodore F Yellowcloud was found guilty of OWI (4th) [Modifiers: Penalty - Operating While under the Influence (4th Offense)], an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Concurrent with: any probation now serving.

Per Statute 343.301(g) your operating privileges for operation of Class D vehicles will require that vehicles owned and/or driven by you be equipped with an ignition interlock device.  Must install a mandatory Ignition Interlock Device when defendant obtains an occupational license or regular license.  There is a $50 ignition interlock surcharge imposed.

miscConds.notes: If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  Fine and costs to be paid on a regular monthly basis, through probation.

records.addlTxt: DA Gerald Fox appears for the State. Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Betthauser.  Defendant plead no contest to Count 1.  OWI 4th, misd.   Count 2 dismissed, but read in for sentencing purposes.  Count 3 dismissed.  Court recited the charge and possible penalties of the charge he plead to.  Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, constitutional rights and elements with the defendant. Defendant understood.  Prior OWI convictions confirmed by the court.  Defense stipulated that there is a factual basis for the plea.  Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily and intelligently entered his plea and waived his constitutional rights. Court found that a factual basis exists for the plea.  Found guilty of count 1.  Joint recommendation for 2 years probation, $2,072.00 fine.  $900 base, includes DNA surcharge.   245 days jail.  All but 29 days stayed.  AODA .  36 month DL rev and IID.  May schedule report date for jail.  Defendant requests 15 days to report.  EMP allowed.  Credit for 2 days served.  Defendant exercised his right to allocution.  Court ordered sentence withheld, 2 years probation.  $2,072.00 fine.  ($900 base fine,  includes DNA surcharge)   245 days jail.  All but first 29 days stayed.  AODA .  36 month DL rev and IID.  Alcohol assessment and DSP.   Schedule report date for jail with probation agent.  Defendant to contact JASO within 48 hours to arrange EMP.  EMP allowed.  Credit for 2 days served.    Court advised defendant of the DNA submission requirement.

Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.  Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle on the highways until properly reinstated in the State of Wisconsin.
Plea/sentencing hearing at 11-09-2015 10:30 am
